p.s: Peter Daszak's goal is to convince his readers to protect nature and wildlife to pretend contact with infected animals living there and stop the spreading of diseases.
To convince his readers make a point, Daszak creates a lot of images through examples and metaphoric language.
This is how he brings the importance of the topic and problems to his readersreaders' attention.
The article starts with a headline that confuses the reader and catches his attention through connecting the topics of pandemic and protection of the rainforests.
The author then starts his text with an example for a disease outbreak that was caused by disturbing the nature.
Through the many details the author uses, like the name of the child (l. 8) the reader gets a very accurate image of the situation, just like while reading a story.
The author then goes on by generalzinggeneralizing this example and states in a short sentence that Every pandemic starts like this (l. 11).
The two other examples he then goes on to write about contain many details as well.
Through naming well known viruses as Ebola, HIV and even the most current one, Covid-19 the author of weeks the readersreaders' interest because he hopes to get a solution at the end of the text.
Also because nowadays nearly everyone is personalypersonally affected by Covid-19.
Following the author explains it is possible to be infected by animals and why rainforests are so important.
Here he uses many numbers.
He also repeats the pattern from line 11 when he states Most pandemics begin... (l. 20) and stresses the importance of the matter by generalizing it.
After explaining how humans destroy the nature imediatelyimmediately connected to humans beeingbeing infected.
Here he uses the personal example of Covid-19 again as the latest of our foes which is transported to a city near you (l. 35).
Through using inclusive language he adressesaddresses the reader direct so he gets the feeling he is involved in the whole situation.
But by using we at the same time the author makes sure the reader does not feel blamed or gets offended but supported to change something.

Espcially when Daszak explains our current approach (l. 33) would not be enough and that it would be neccessarynecessary to stop the spreading from the beginning he uses a lot of inclusive language and dramatic contrasts such as while we wait [...] hundrets of people have died (l. 38) and dramatic frightening numbers (l. 41) to stress the importance to act together.
Following he gives solutions to the readers on what has to be changed.
He stresses the power of the consumers through giving a positive, successfullsuccessful example of campaigns against palm oil (l. 48).
And then even explains the Corona crisis should be seen as a chance for a new start.
By using the metaphor to green our economies he again refers to the importance of nature for the prevention of diseases.
He ends his article with the thesis only by accepting the influence humans and their behavior had on nature and then causing the pandemic things might change for the future.

All in all, the author starts his article with examples on how diseases spread, then gives explenationsexplanations for these processes and finalyfinally names things people should todo to prevent happenings like this for the future.

To convince the reader the author uses simple but professional language and explains terms like Anthropocene (l. 29) so his readers can follow his argumentation easier and still get the fealingfeeling his text is professional.

For the same reason he also uses many numbers and facts, but at the same time gives many detailleddetailed examples that resemble little stories, so his readers can imagine the consequences of disturbing the nature better.
